description: Unaccented variant of master, attested since the 15th century.

entries.meaning: A title conferred on an adult male, usually when the name is unknown. Also used as a term of address, often by a parent to a young child.

verbs.description: mister (third-person singular simple present misters, present participle mistering, simple past and past participle mistered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To address by the title of "mister". [from 18th c.]
examples: “Hush! hush! Mr. Sikes,” said the Jew, trembling; “don’t speak so loud!”“None of your mistering,” replied the ruffian; “you always mean mischief when you come that. You know my name: out with it! I shan’t disgrace it when the time comes.”

description: From Middle English mister, myster, from Anglo-Norman mester, meister (et al.), from Latin misterium, a medieval conflation of Latin ministerium (“ministry”) with Latin mysterium (“mystery”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Someone's business or function; an occupation, employment, trade.
(now rare, dialectal) A kind, type of.

verbs.description: mister (third-person singular simple present misters, present participle mistering, simple past and past participle mistered)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, impersonal) To be necessary; to matter.
examples: As for my name, it mistreth not to tell;Call me the Squyre of Dames that me beseemeth well.

entries.meaning: A device that makes or sprays mist.
examples: Odessa D. uses a mister Sunday to fight the 106-degree heat at a NASCAR race in Fontana, California.
